explanation:
To determine whether OS_SocketShutdown (or anything it transitively calls) uses the C library function memcmp to compare null-terminated strings, the analyzer must inspect all direct callees and any symbols/macros/data structures used by the target that could contain or trigger such usage. The items above are included because:

- OS_SocketShutdown_Impl — direct callee of the target; must be inspected for any memcmp usage or calls that do string comparisons.
- OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIdRelease — direct callees; their implementations (or transitive callees) might use memcmp when matching names/IDs.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken — called by OS_SocketShutdown_Impl (per graph); could perform name/index lookups that use memcmp.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel — internal callees of OS_ObjectIdGetById per the call graph; include to allow full transitive inspection for memcmp usage.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — macro used to obtain the stream record; need its definition to see if it expands to any code that does string comparisons.
- OS_stream_internal_record_t and the socket-related constants (OS_SocketDomain_INVALID, OS_SocketType_STREAM, OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED, OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE, OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE) — the struct/type definitions are required to understand what fields are accessed/modified and whether any hidden string operations occur via accessor macros or inline functions.
- BUGCHECK and OS_ERR_INVALID_ARGUMENT — the BUGCHECK macro could expand to logging/assertion code that might call functions (e.g., OS_printf, UT asserts) which could use memcmp; inspect its expansion to be safe.
- OS_printf — reachable from the target (via BUGCHECK or other paths); print/logging helpers sometimes call formatting helpers that could use string comparisons.
- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr and their helper symbols (UT_GetStubEntry, UT_ClearStubEntry, UT_SetHandlerFunction, UT_DefaultStubImpl, UtAssert_Abort, UtAssert_GetContext) — the unit-test stub framework appears in the call graph and could be part of inlined/test instrumentation. If present in the build, these stubs or their helpers might call or wrap functions that use memcmp for comparing names/contexts; include them to ensure no transitive memcmp usage is missed.

In short: to prove compliance with the MISRA rule you must inspect the target and all reachable code (direct callees and transitive callees, plus macros/structs used) for occurrences of memcmp used to compare null-terminated strings. The symbols above cover the target's direct callees, their internal callees (per the static call graph), and the macros/types referenced by the target so the next analysis agent can examine those definitions/implementations for any disallowed memcmp usage.
